data.meta_site_name: The JH Movie Collection's Official Wiki
data.text:
For Sky's headquarters, see Sky Campus.

For the defunct animation studio owned by Disney, see Blue Sky Studios.

Production and distribution company owned by SkyTemplate:SHORTDESC:Production and distribution company owned by Sky

Sky Studios is a production company founded by Sky in June 2019 with assets from the now defunct Sky Vision.[2] It develops, produces and funds original drama, comedy and documentary, and has investments in a number of production businesses in the UK and US: Love Productions (wholly owned), Bad Wolf,[3] Blast Films!, Sugar Films, True North Productions, Chrysalis Vision, True to Nature, Longboat Pictures and The Lighthouse[4][5] in the United Kingdom; Jupiter Entertainment, Talos Films, Znak & Co. and Catalina Content[6] in the United States.[7]

As part of the launch of Sky Studios, the broadcaster also announced that they would double their spend on original productions to over $1.3 billion over the next five years.[8][9]

In September 2019, Sky Studios announced they were launching a US-arm called The Hive, based in New York and Tennessee, utilising expertise from Jupiter Entertainment.[10][11]

Sky Studios Elstree[]

In December 2019, Sky announced plans to develop Sky Studios Elstree.[12] The facility will be built at Rowley Lane, located close to the existing Elstree Studios. The new studios are expected to open in 2022, and will provide production space for Sky's original content as well as film and TV productions from NBCUniversal, which is owned by Sky's parent company Comcast.[13]

It is expected that the facility will have 14 stages, with the smallest being approximately Template:Cvt.[14] The site is also expected to house post-production facilities and an on-site screening cinema.[15]

Partnerships[]

Sky Studios has creative partnerships in place with a range of production companies including Merman TV[16] (founded by Sharon Horgan and Clelia Mountford), Rangabee[17] (founded by Romesh Ranganathan and Benjamin Green), The Apartment[18] (part of Fremantle and led by Lorenzo Mieli) and an overall deal with German filmmaker Philipp Leinemann.[19]
